title: Present Perfect or Past Simple
instructions: Complete the sentences with the verbs in brackets. Use B1present perfectB2 or B1past simpleB2.

sentence: (not meet) Frank for two weeks. Does he still work here?' 'I don't know. I
(not see) him since last week's meeting.'
explain: Corr: haven't met. We need present perfect here because the time period 'for two weeks' comes up to now.
Corr: haven't seen. We need present perfect here because we consider the time period that started at last week's meeting and comes up to now.

sentence: (Sally / be) the manager at this department?' 'She
(come) here six years ago. First, for about a year she
(be) a manager assistant, but then she
explain: Corr: has Sally been. We need present perfect here because Sally is still the manager and we ask about a time period (how long) that comes up to now.
Corr: came. There's a time adverb: six years ago, so we need past simple.
Corr: was. Although there is a 'for about year' time adverb in the sentence, this time period doesn't come up to now, it ended in the past.
Corr: became. We need the past simple here because there is a time adverb: but then.

sentence: 'I'm on a slimming diet and I
(lose) six pounds since last month.' 'Congratulations. I
(lose) a few pounds too, since I
explain: Corr: have lost. We need present perfect because of 'since last month', which means we consider the time period since last month up to now.
Corr: have lost. We need present perfect here because we consider the time period that started in the past (when he started...) and comes up to now.
Corr: began. We need past simple here because it is in the 'since' part of the sentence.
